definitions.definition: To pull along a surface or through a medium, sometimes with difficulty.
definitions.example: Let's drag this load of wood over to the shed.

definitions.definition: To move onward heavily, laboriously, or slowly; to advance with weary effort; to go on lingeringly.
definitions.example: Time seems to drag when you’re waiting for a bus.

definitions.definition: To act or proceed slowly or without enthusiasm; to be reluctant.
To draw along (something burdensome); hence, to pass in pain or with difficulty.
To serve as a clog or hindrance; to hold back.
To move (an item) on the computer display by means of a mouse or other input device.
definitions.example: Drag the file into the window to open it.

definitions.definition: (chiefly of a vehicle) To unintentionally rub or scrape on a surface.
definitions.example: The car was so low to the ground that its muffler was dragging on a speed bump.

definitions.definition: To hit or kick off target.
To search for something, as a lost object or body, by dragging something along the bottom of a body of water.
To break (land) by drawing a drag or harrow over it; to harrow.
To search exhaustively, as if with a dragnet.
To roast, say negative things about, or call attention to the flaws of (someone).
definitions.example: You just drag him 'cause he's got more money than you.

definitions.definition: To perform as a drag queen or drag king.
An instance of something being dragged.
